DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

China's Vice Premier Liu said China's economy is set to meet the 6.5% growth target this year and that all indicators point to stability in the economy, while he added that China is experiencing a shift towards a consumption driven economy. Furthermore, Liu commented that China wants a negotiated solution on trade which is based on mutual respect and that no-one has ever emerged as a winner after a trade war. (Newswires)

China's US envoy said selling or reducing purchases of US Treasuries would be very dangerous like playing with fire, while the envoy doesn't think anybody in Beijing is seriously thinking about pulling back from US Treasury debt market should tensions worsen. (Newswires)

RBNZ Financial Stability Report said it is to ease loan-to-value ratio restrictions and said that households remain exposed to financial shocks due to their large mortgage debt burden, while it added that mortgage credit growth and house price inflation have eased to more sustainable rates. However, RBNZ later commented said they are some way away from LVRS being fully removed. (Newswires)


UK/EU

UK PM May said all sides want the future relationship decided by the end of 2020 and that the backstop is to be considered in a short time period if no future arrangement is sorted, while she added confidence and supply agreement with DUP continues and that she is looking ahead to the vote. (Newswires)

EU Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier reportedly told MEPs that the Brexit deal will be referred back to the European Council if it is voted against on December 11th. (Yahoo)

Irish PM Varadkar said a no deal Brexit situation is "unlikely". (Newswires)

ITV's Peston wrote "According to senior Labour sources, Corbyn is close to agreeing that shortly (days) after the loss of the meaningful vote by May, he would formally make his party the champion of another referendum or People’s Vote". (Facebook)

Negotiators for UK and US are meeting on Wednesday in Washington for what they expect to be the final round of talks over services agreement. (FT)

Italy Deputy PM Salvini said we will do all we can to avoid any EU disciplinary action and hopes for reciprocal openness from EU. (Newswires)

French Finance Minister Le Maire is reportedly calling for deeper tax cuts than originally planned. (Newswires)
 

FX

S&P affirmed Canada at AAA/A-1+; outlook stable. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (23 Nov) +3.453mln vs. Exp. +0.8mln (Prev. -1.5mln). (Newswires)

Officials in many OPEC countries said the need for collective action to halt the oil price rout outweighs the risk of riling a US president who has publicly accused them of plotting to keep prices high, while the report noted that with Brent around USD 60 per barrel, oil prices are below levels many OPEC and allied nations need to balance their budgets. (WSJ)

Kuwaiti Oil Minister said it is too early to talk about OPEC+ cuts. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

Israel's U.N. Ambassador Danny Danon said the US has spoken with Israel about possibly presenting a long-awaited Middle East peace plan at the start of next year. (Newswires)
 

US

White House Economic Advisor Kudlow said President Trump means what he says in which he could hike tariffs if no constructive talks occur at G20 and that the White House is disappointed in China's response to trade issues. However, Kudlow also commented that Trump is open to a deal with China and China must deal with IP theft as well as tariff barriers, while he added the raising of tariffs to 25% is not a "certainty" but described it as "scheduled". (Newswires)

US President Trump may impose auto tariffs as early as next week according to reports which recommended a 25% tariff on all EU auto imports, while Canada and Mexico are said to be exempted. (WiWo)

Some of US President Trump's top advisers were not happy with his comments to the WSJ the prior day amid fears that they could make the high-stakes meetings with Xi even more difficult. (Politico)

Fed's Clarida (Voter) stated that it is especially important to look at a range of data points at this point in the US rate hike cycle and that he would be in favour of further rate hikes if inflation surprises to the upside, while he added the rate is currently 'just-below' the Fed's longer-term neutral estimates. (Newswires)

Fed's Bullard (Non-voter, Dove) said he does not expect low unemployment to spark inflation and that the US economy and job market is strong with only moderate financial risks. Bullard added rates are already at or near neutral and that he expects slower growth over next two years making it more 'tougher' for fed to continue rate hikes, while he also noted possible 'cracks' in growth to shape Fed debate in coming year. (Newswires)

US Consumer Confidence Nov 135.7 vs. Exp. 135.9 (Prev. 137.9, Rev. 137.9). (Newswires)
 

MARKET RECAP

PG&E (PCG) and Edison International (EIX) continued their recovery as a legislative bill gains traction, helping to burden wildfire-related costs. Vertex (VRTX) moved higher after the pharmaceutical announced that three studies met their primary end-points. Airlines (DAL, UAL, LUV, SAVE) opened higher following Spirit Airlines (SAVE) raising its full year TRASM guidance. Retail stocks (M, KSS, TGT, AMZN) were among the top performers due to strong Black Friday and Cyber Monday sales; particularly Amazon which reported its best ever single day sales. Netflix (NFLX) announced a Roald Dahl project. United Technologies (UTX) underperformed after announcing a major business restructuring. Apple (AAPL) opened lower due to Trump threatening tariffs on the co.’s products, though pared losses over the course of the session. Bristol-Myers (BMY) nosedived after a lung-cancer treatment missed its primary endpoint. Hormel Foods (HRL) traded lower on the back of a downgrade at Jefferies. Facebook (FB) fell in the wake of further scrutiny in its handling of the Russia data scandal. General Motors (GM) saw downticks on a tweet from Trump saying he is mulling cutting subsidies for electric cars for the automaker. Raymond James (RJF) drifted lower whilst being initiated with a neutral at Goldman. Steel stocks (NUE, X, AKS) traded lower following reports that Chinese steel mills are preparing for challenges as margins fall. SPX +0.33% at 2682, NDX +0.34% at 6701, DJI +0.44% at 24749.

The Treasury complex ended Tuesday’s session pretty much unchanged, trading in a 7-tick range, holding on to the gains just after Monday’s market close after US President Trump announced his intention to go ahead with raising tariffs on China imports. Very limited reaction was seen on Fed’s Vice Chair Clarida reiterated the importance of data dependency in the Fed’s policy approach. Most of the action was concentrated in the belly of the curve, where yields were lower by around 1bps at settlement. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 3+ ticks higher at 119-08.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 27 November 2018: Stocks bounce back after early wobble
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.
 

US MARKET WRAP – 27 November 2018: Stocks bounce back after early wobble

* SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, treasuries up, dollar up, crude down.

* REAR-VIEW: Trump’s top advisers unhappy with 10%-25% China tariffs intention, Kudlow says Trump open to deal with China, Fed’s Clarida urges data dependency, Fed’s Bullard sees rate near neutral, Italy seeks budget deficit 2.2%-2.3%, rumours over second Brexit referendum.

* AHEAD: US GDP 2nd Estimate, PCE Preliminary Prices and Advanced Goods Trade Balance, Fed Financial Stability Report, ECB's Lautenschlager, Rehn, Coeure, Praet and de Guindos to speak, Fed Chair Powell to speak, BoE's Carney Speaking & Publication of Financial Stability, Annual Bank Stress Tests, Brexit Assessment and Withdrawal Scenarios.

 

* TRADE: White House Economic Advisor Kudlow said US President Trump was open to a deal with China, noting the raising of tariffs to 25% was not a "certainty," but described the upcoming hike as "scheduled". He urged China to deal with IP theft and tariff barriers while talking up the US economy and criticising China’s. At the same conference, White House National Security Advisor Bolton also appeared optimistic on the relationship that Trump has developed with China's Xi. Earlier in the session, Politico reported that some of Trump's top advisers were not happy with his Monday interview with the WSJ, where he announced his intention to go ahead with tariffs on China imports from 10% to 25% in January. Advisers raised fears that the latest announcement could make the high-stakes meetings at the G20 (30/Nov-1/Dec) with Xi even more difficult. Apple’s shares faced pressure on Tuesday after Trump opened the possibility of tariffs being placed on iPhones from China while EU automakers suffered losses after reports in WiWo suggested that the US could impose auto tariffs as early as next week; a Commerce Department spokesperson later stated that the final findings on the 232 automotive tariffs investigation have not been submitted to the President. The Chinese Ambassador to the US warns of dire consequences if the trade war leads to economic separation; China prefers a negotiated solution.  

* FED: Fed's Vice Chair Clarida (Voter) stressed that it is especially important to look at a range of data points at this time in the US rate-hike cycle; he could be in favour of further rate hikes if inflation surprises to the upside. He noted that the rate is currently 'just below' Fed's longer-term neutral estimates, urging more data dependency as policy moves towards neutral estimates. His opinion is that uncertainty regarding neutral policy and full employment highlights the need for data dependency. Fed's Bullard (Non-voter, Dove) stated that rates are already at or near neutral while he does not expect low unemployment to spark inflation; he highlighted that the US economy and job market appear strong with only moderate financial risks though he expects slower growth over next two years making it more 'tougher' for the Fed to continue rate hikes; he sees possible 'cracks' in growth to shape Fed debate in coming year. Fed's George (Voter, Hawk) said unemployment is "very ow" in the US, causing labour shortages. Fed's Evans (Non-Voter, Dove) believes it is time to return to a more neutral policy stance; he noted that the planned closing of GM plants adds to challenges in the US manufacturing sector while businesses are finding it difficult to find high skilled labour. He added the automotive sector is strong through the recovery but is facing challenges now. Fed's Bostic (Voter, Dovish) said the "positive" overall economy still leaves "pockets of distress".

* BREXIT: The European top court said on Tuesday that it would make a decision on whether the UK can unilaterally reverse the decision to leave the bloc, opening the possibility to a second referendum. The claim was raised by Scottish MPS, MEPs and MSPs who believe that revoking A50 would "ride roughshod" over EU principles. Even a formerly loyal PM May’s supporter, Fallon, denounced the draft withdrawal agreement as the worst of all worlds and suggested a delay to try and get better terms. In related news, Labour sources suggested that Opposition Leader Corbyn would call a second vote shortly after PM May’s defeat on the meaningful vote in Parliament on the basis that there is no consensus on what happens next, rumours that were nonetheless later denied. Meanwhile, UK PM May opposed criticism raised by US President Trump over her deal after he warned on Monday that the UK may not be able to strike a trade deal with the US on current terms. PM May, in response, claimed to have an independent trade policy and stated they have already talked with the US about future trade talks while announcing she will not meet Trump at the G20. Also note UK and US negotiators are meeting on Wednesday in Washington for what they expect to be the final round of talks over services agreement.

* ITALY: The EU commission are still in open dialogue with Italy over the budget, as discussions are now set to continue at the G20 meeting. EU’s Moscovici told the Italian government that he is open to seeking a solution with the country as he favours encouragement to sanctions while a draft showed EU Governments are backing the EU Commission view that disciplinary procedure over debt is warranted. With regards to the figures, the 2019 deficit/GDP target is almost certain to be 2.2%-2.3%, as suggested by the League’s Economic Advisor Siri, while PM Conte reportedly anticipates EUR 3.6bln of budget cuts.

* CONSUMER CONFIDENCE: The index dropped to 135.7 from 137.9, only a tad below the 135.9 consensus. The weakness in this reading was attributed to the expectations component, which is sensitive to stock market volatility. Nonetheless, analysts at Pantheon Macroeconomics said that the survey remains solid showing gains spread across buying plans for homes and cars contributing strongly to business conditions. Looking ahead, they warn that “the continued volatility in the stock market usually would signal further declines in expectations and headline confidence, but the plunge in oil prices is now driving down retail gas prices, which will act as an offset”.

* SPX +0.33% at 2682, NDX +0.34% at 6701, DJI +0.44% at 24749. SECTORS: Energy -0.33%, Materials -1.25%, Industrials -0.24%, Cons Discretionary +0.24%, Cons Staples +0.92%, Healthcare +1.00%, Financials +0.05%, Tech +0.24%, Telecoms +0.57%, Utilities +0.87%.

*STOCK SPECIFICS: PG&E (PCG) and Edison International (EIX) continued their recovery as a legislative bill gains traction, helping to burden wildfire-related costs. Vertex (VRTX) moved higher after the pharmaceutical announced that three studies met their primary end-points. Airlines (DAL, UAL, LUV, SAVE) opened higher following Spirit Airlines (SAVE) raising its full year TRASM guidance. Retail stocks (M, KSS, TGT, AMZN) were among the top performers due to strong Black Friday and Cyber Monday sales; particularly Amazon which reported its best ever single day sales. Netflix (NFLX) announced a Roald Dahl project. United Technologies (UTX) underperformed after announcing a major business restructuring. Apple (AAPL) opened lower due to Trump threatening tariffs on the co.’s products, though pared losses over the course of the session. Bristol-Myers (BMY) nosedived after a lung-cancer treatment missed its primary endpoint. Hormel Foods (HRL) traded lower on the back of a downgrade at Jefferies. Facebook (FB) fell in the wake of further scrutiny in its handling of the Russia data scandal. General Motors (GM) saw downticks on a tweet from Trump saying he is mulling cutting subsidies for electric cars for the automaker. Raymond James (RJF) drifted lower whilst being initiated with a neutral at Goldman. Steel stocks (NUE, X, AKS) traded lower following reports that Chinese steel mills are preparing for challenges as margins fall.

* WTI (F9) SETTLES USD 0.07 LOWER AT USD 51.56/BBL, BRENT (F9) SETTLES USD 0.27 LOWER AT USD 60.21/BBL. Attention is now on the OPEC meeting between 6-7 December in Vienna, where a consensus is building that the cartel will make moves to trim oil production. The market will be looking for hints at the G20, which is set to feature appearances from the Saudi and Russian energy ministers. Ahead of that meeting, however, WSJ reported officials in many OPEC countries say the need for collective action to halt the oil price rout outweighs the risk of riling a US president who has publicly accused them of plotting to keep prices high; the article noted that with Brent around $60 per barrel, oil prices were below levels many OPEC and allied nations need to balance their budgets. WSJ also said that producers have been coy about plans to reduce their production amid President Trump's public chiding on Twitter, as well as private threats made to Saudi Arabia that he would back legislation aimed at making OPEC an illegal cartel. Tomorrow, the Saudi energy minister and his Nigerian counterpart will be giving a press conference at 0900 GMT, which will help shape expectations for potential comments at the G20.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLE 3+ TICKS HIGHER AT 119-08. The Treasury complex ended Tuesday’s session pretty much unchanged, trading in a 7-tick range, holding on to the gains just after Monday’s market close after US President Trump announced his intention to go ahead with raising tariffs on China imports. Very limited reaction was seen on Fed’s Vice Chair Clarida reiterated the importance of data dependency in the Fed’s policy approach. Most of the action was concentrated in the belly of the curve, where yields were lower by around 1bps at settlement.  

* 5-YEAR NOTES AUCTION: The treasury sold USD 40bln in 5yr notes on the screws at a high yield of 2.88%. The bid-to-cover came in at 2.49x well above recent averages indicating decent demand for the auction. Directs were awarded a portion significantly higher than recent averages while indirects were awarded a share well within recent average. Dealers were left with a smaller portion than previously seen.

* USD: The Dollar has retained an underlying bid, albeit not across the board as its Antipodean counterparts and many EM rivals regain some composure after recent underperformance. Early month end portfolio models are flagging a modest Greenback buy signal vs all G10 rivals, while HIA and SOMA flows are also supportive. Hence, the index has consolidated gains above 97.000 and may climb further above the big figure from a technical perspective if it closes above a major Fib (97.068), with the next upside chart resistance levels at 97.406 and 97.693 (current ytd high).

* EUR: The single currency has come under renewed pressure and is probing just below 1.1300 vs the Usd on the back of reports via German media that the US could impose the pending 25% auto tariffs as soon as next week (post-G20 Summit). On clear break of the round number, further stops are seen around 1.1290, but similar sell orders said to be triggered on a break of 1.1310 did not prompt an aggressive slide in the headline pair, so it appears that there are hefty bids on the way down.

* GBP: Brexit remains the big independent weight for Sterling as opposition to UK PM May’s Brexit deal stacks up ahead of the December 11 meaningful vote, and includes a so-called loyal supporter, Fallon, who denounced the draft withdrawal agreement as the worst of all worlds and suggested a delay to try and get better terms. However, the EU has persistently warned there is no return to the negotiating table and Cable has extended losses under 1.2800 and briefly through the 100 DMA vs Eur, but so far holding in above recent lows (1.2724 and 0.8900+ respectively).

* JPY: A break from the norm or possibly just a short-term deviation, but as US-China trade tensions ramp up ahead of US President Trump’s meeting with Chinese peer Xi, the Usd is benefiting more from safe-haven positioning with gains vs the yen through a couple of Fibs (113.48 and 113.79) towards 114.00.

* NZD, AUD, SEK, NOK: All ending Tuesday’s session at the top of the major rankings, and largely in corrective and technical trade, as the Kiwi shrugged off more downbeat NZ data (trade after retail sales yesterday) to retest 0.6800 with the aid of some bullish cross-winds as Aud/Nzd retreated from just shy of 1.0700 to sub-1.0650 again and Aud/Usd languished closer to the base of a 0.7215-70 range. Elsewhere, the Sek also largely ignored weaker than forecast Swedish releases in the form of trade, and softer PPI prints to trade up near 10.2600 vs the Eur, while Eur/Nok eased just a few pips below 9.7100 at best.

  • Talks between Trump and Xi may not conclude with a formal statement; sees opportunity for Xi to "change the tone"
  • Doesn't expect any formal meetings in Buenos Aires to lay groundwork for Trump-Xi meeting

subject: Daily FX Wrap: DXY eyeing key tech level as Eur driven down in late trade
content:
USD

The Dollar has retained an underlying bid, albeit not across the board as its Antipodean counterparts and many EM rivals regain some composure after recent underperformance. Early month end portfolio models are flagging a modest Greenback buy signal vs all G10 rivals, while HIA and SOMA flows are also supportive. Hence, the index has consolidated gains above 97.000 and may climb further above the big figure from a technical perspective if it closes above a major Fib (97.068), with the next upside chart resistance levels at 97.406 and 97.693 (current ytd high).

EUR

The single currency has come under renewed pressure and is probing just below 1.1300 vs the Usd on the back of reports via German media that the US could impose the pending 25% auto tariffs as soon as next week (post-G20 Summit). On clear break of the round number, further stops are seen around 1.1290, but similar sell orders said to be triggered on a break of 1.1310 did not prompt an aggressive slide in the headline pair, so it appears that there are hefty bids on the way down.

GBP

Brexit remains the big independent weight for Sterling as opposition to UK PM May’s Brexit deal stacks up ahead of the December 11 meaningful vote, and includes a so called loyal supporter, Fallon, who denounced the draft withdrawal agreement as the worst of all worlds and suggested a delay to try and get better terms. However, the EU has persistently warned there is no return to the negotiating table and Cable has extended losses under 1.2800 and briefly through the 100 DMA vs Eur, but so far holding in above recent lows (1.2724 and 0.8900+ respectively).

JPY

A break from the norm or possibly just a short term deviation, but as US-China trade tensions ramp up ahead of US President Trump’s meeting with Chinese peer Xi, the Usd is benefiting more from safe-haven positioning with gains vs the yen through a couple of Fibs (113.48 and 113.79) towards 114.00.

NZD/AUD/SEK/NOK

All ending Tuesday’s EU session at the top of the major rankings, and largely in corrective and technical trade, as the Kiwi shrugged off more downbeat NZ data (trade after retail sales yesterday) to retest 0.6800 with the aid of some bullish cross-winds as Aud/Nzd retreated from just shy of 1.0700 to sub-1.0650 again and Aud/Usd languished closer to the base of a 0.7215-70 range. Elsewhere, the Sek also largely ignored weaker than forecast Swedish releases in the form of trade, and softer PPI prints to trade up near 10.2600 vs the Eur, while Eur/Nok eased just a few pips below 9.7100 at best.

content: Not much market reaction to latest rhetoric from Fed’s Clarida, though on balance his comments appear slightly less dovish than earlier in November, with the overall message underlining data dependency and in particular monitoring inflation expectations. However, core bonds are nestling nearer session lows (160.82 for Bunds and 122.93 in Gilts), with US Treasuries essentially flat-lining in the run up to 5 year supply, and no further developments on Brexit, Italy’s budget or US-China trade after all the early flurry of headlines and reports. Meanwhile, the Usd retains a firm underlying bid on multiple factors, but not across the board as high yielders and EMs claw back some recent losses.

  • United Technologies (UTX) – Following the industrial co.’s acquisition of Rockwell Collins (COL), it will split into three independent companies: aerospace, elevators and buildings. The co. expects the separation to be completed within 18-24 months as well as USD 500mln in synergies from the Rockwell Collins acquisition. UTX expects one-time costs of USD 2.5bln-3bln from the separation. (Newswires)

S&P500

Separately, BMO Capital lowered its price target to USD 56 due to the "surprising" failure of CM-451 and CM-331 suggesting the co. "will likely not be competitive" in small-cell lung cancer. (Newswires)

Elsewhere, AWS has launched RoboMaker, a service used to develop intelligent robotics applications at scale. WSJ reports that the co. is now in third position for the largest player in the US digital advertisement market, establishing itself as a serious competitor in the space against Google (GOOGL) and Facebook (FB). (Newswires/WSJ)
  • Facebook (FB) – BI reports that British lawmakers may reveal documents that could prove CEO Mark Zuckerberg was implicit in the Cambridge Analytica scandal. Elsewhere, the Chief Business Officer of WhatsApp Neeraj Arora is departing from the co. CNBC reports that the social media co. is moving its target audience for the FB Watch platform to users aged 30 years or older. A UK lawmaker state that the social media was aware of the data harvesting made by Russia back in 2014. (BI/CNBC/Newswires)
  • Micron Technology (MU) – UBS has cut its price target on the semiconductor co. to USD 41. (Newswires)
  • PayPal (PYPL) – UK regulators are looking into the payment co.’s USD 2.2bln acquisition of the European fintech startup iZettle, over concerns of potential antitrust issues. (WSJ)
  • Tesla (TSLA) – The China Passenger Car Association has said that Tesla car sales in China have dropped by 70% compared with October 2017; selling just 211 cars in China this October. Elsewhere, the SEC chairman Jay Clayton has said the SEC is finished looking into the securities fraud settlement against CEO Elon Musk. (Newswires)

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 27th November 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • US President Trump said he still intends to go ahead with raising tariffs on China imports from 10% to 25% and that it was highly unlikely he would accept China’s request to refrain from the increase.
  • Italy's League economic advisor Siri says Italy are considering reducing the budget deficit to 2.2-2.3%
  • Senior UK lawmaker Fallon says it may be possible to delay the date the UK leaves the EU to negotiate a better deal.
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US API Weekly Data, Fed's Clarida, Bostic, George & Evans, ECB's Mersch, & Costa and Riksbank's Ohlsson.

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly positive as the region took impetus from the performance on Wall St, where all majors finished with firm gains on return from the Thanksgiving weekend and with retailers buoyed on the back of Black Friday and Cyber Monday sales. ASX 200 (+1.0%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) were lifted from the open with Australia led higher by tech and financials, while a pullback in USD/JPY limited the upside for the Japanese benchmark. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were mixed with China somewhat dampened by Trump’s hardball tactics ahead of the meeting with Chinese President Xi at this week’s G20, in which he suggested an intention to proceed with raising tariffs on China imports from 10% to 25% and also warned to place tariffs on the remaining USD 267bln of Chinese imports if they fail to reach a favourable outcome for the US. Furthermore, a slowdown of Chinese Industrial Profit growth and concerns in the Hong Kong property sector also contributed the cautiousness in Chinese markets. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful as prices took a breather from its extended but gradual uptrend and with today’s 40yr auction largely ignored despite increases in the b/c and accepted prices.

PBoC skipped open market operations for the 23rd consecutive occasion. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9463 (Prev. 6.9453)

Chinese Industrial Profits (Oct) Y/Y 3.6% (Prev. 4.1%). (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM May's spokesman said PM May still believes she can win the meaningful vote on Brexit and is focused on winning first time round, while the meaningful vote is expected on Tuesday 11th December and an official confirmed five days of debate between December 4th to December 11th. (Newswires)

Following comments from US President Trump, that as the Brexit deal stands it sounds like the UK may not be able to trade with thr US. a UK No. 10 spokesperson later said declaration signed with EU is clear that UK can sign trade deals with the US and that UK has already been laying the groundwork for an ambitious trade deal with the US. (Newswires)

Senior UK lawmaker Fallon says it may be possible to delay the date UK leaves the EU to negotiate a better deal. (Newswires)

Buzzfeed's Wickham tweets "Row brewing with No10 due to release Geoffrey Cox's legal advice on the deal. The advice on the backstop given to cabinet was "damning" and essentially said UK cannot get out, according to cabinet sources." (Newswires)

UK PM May's Spokesperson says that the Governments economic analysis of a range of different Brexit scenarios will be published tomorrow. Adding that the government will not revoke Article 50 Brexit notice, and PM May has no plans to meet with US President Trump at G20 summit (Newswires)

EU's Nowotny said a well communicated exit from QE may benefit financial health and poses little risk to financial stability, while he added very low rates for a long time may impair stability. (Newswires)

Italian PM Conte, following a meeting with Deputy PMs Salvini and Di Maio stated that the government will stick to its high-spending budget plans. (BBC) Later it was reported Italy’s 2019 deficit/GDP target is almost certain to be 2.2%, while PM Conte reportedly anticipates EUR 3.6bln of budget cuts according to reports in Messagerro. (Messagerro)

Head of Italian Finance Committee says there is neither a political nor economic reason to change the structure of 2019 budget. (Newswires)

EU’s Moscovici says the EU commission are still in dialogue with Italy regarding the budget, adding that the Italian budget will be discussed at G20 meeting. Moscovici says to the Italian government that he is open to seeking a solution on the budget; adding that he prefers encouragement to sanctions. (Newswires)

Italian Deputy PM Salvini says that no new documents are to go to the EU on the budget, (ANSA)

Italy's Lower House is looking to start the budget debate on December 3rd (ANSA)

Italy's League economic advisor Siri says Italy are considering reducing the budget deficit to 2.2-2.3%. Adding that the government won’t postpone key welfare and pension reforms, with welfare and pension decree to be approved by Christmas. (Newswires)

EU Trade Commissioner Malmstrom suggests constructive EU discussions with the US on reforms of the WTO. (Newswires)

EU are to promote positive trade agenda including reform of WTO at the G20 summit. (Newswires)

US

US President Trump said he still intends to go ahead with raising tariffs on China imports from 10% to 25% and that it was highly unlikely he would accept China’s request to refrain from the increase. Trump also suggested he would place tariffs on the rest of Chinese imports that are currently not subject to tariffs if the US doesn’t make a deal with China, while he added tariffs could be placed on Apple iPhones from China and that consumers could stand a 10% tariff on iPhones. (WSJ)

Chinese Foreign Ministry Spokesman Geng says US President Trump and Chinese President Xi have agreed to reach a mutually beneficial agreement. Was subsequently reported that Chinese Foreign Ministry Spokesman Geng was referring to a November 1st phone call.

US Special Counsel Mueller's office said former Trump campaign manager Manafort lied to FBI and Special Counsel in violation of plea agreement. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

US Secretary of State Pompeo said Russia actions in the Kersch Strait is a dangerous escalation and in violation of international law. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European cash indices gave up initial gains (Eurostoxx 50 -0.1%) following a relatively flat open after pre-market gains in index futures were short-lived. Equity futures staged a pre-cash open rally after it was reported that a Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman was quoted as stating that US President Xi and US President Trump had agreed to mutually beneficial agreements. However gains in futures markets were pared after it was later reported that this was in reference to a November 1st phone call and thus was viewed as stale by the market, particularly considering the hardball interview by Trump in the WSJ yesterday ahead of this week’s G20 summit. On an index basis, the SMI lags its peers (-0.5%) with Credit Suisse (-1.7%) lower following a broker downgrade at Credit Suisse.

In terms of sector specifics, performance is relatively mixed with slight underperformance in material names in-fitting with recent price action in the complex. To the upside, utility names modestly outperform, albeit the moves thus far across the board are relatively small in terms of magnitude.

Individual movers this morning include Dialog Semiconductor (-1.4%) amid Apple-inspired losses (post-Trump threat of potential tariffs on iPhones and laptops), Apple share are down 1.7% pre-market. Elsewhere, Rexel (+1.9%) are firmer following a broker upgrade at Credit Suisse, Thomas Cook (-24.5%) shares are notably underperforming following a disappointing trading update, dragging Tui (-4.2%) lower in sympathy.

FX

GBP – The standout underperformer vs. peers amid comments from UK Remain loyalist Fallon who said it may be possible to delay the date UK leaves the EU to renegotiate a better deal, inflicting a blow to UK PM May’s so-called “best deal”. As such Cable fell to a low print of 1.2734 ahead of the mid-November base at 1.2724, having already given up the 1.2800 handle following comments from US President Trump who noted that UK may not be able to trade with the US, in an interview last night. If the mid-November low (or Raab trough) is breached, the next levels to note are 1.2696 (October low) and 1.2662 (YTD low). However, looking further ahead Credit Suisse is more optimistic on the outlook for Sterling, with their Cable forecast at 1.4000 by end-2019.

DXY – Overall bid vs G10 counterparts with the aid of the GBP weakness due to the latest Brexit developments. Moreover, Citi’s rebalancing model points to modest USD buying vs. peers going into month end, while Nordea also notes tomorrow’s HIA which is the cut-off date if companies wish to convert foreign currency into USD along with SOMA that happens to fall on Friday as well. The index is currently hovering above 97.000 within a narrow range around the big figure.

EUR – Holding up well vs. the pound above 0.8850 but not quite challenging the 100DMA 0.8884, though the single currency is lower vs. the buck, with the pair tripping some stops at 1.1310. Obviously, 1.1300 is nearest support and if breached more stops are reported at 1.1290.

JPY – Reports from a Chinese Ministry spokesman noting US President Trump and Chinese President Xi have agreed to reach a mutually beneficial agreement saw the Japanese currency extend losses vs. the greenback through a Fib level at 113.48 and reaching highs of 113.66 (shy of the next Fib at 113.76), before pairing a bulk of the move as it quickly emerged that the comments were made initially in wake of a phone call between the two leader back on November 1st.

NZD,AUD – Notable, albeit marginal G10 outperformers vs. the buck, with the Kiwi staging another recovery following the weak data (trade overnight), and now looking ahead to the RBNZ semi-annual FSR tonight. NZD/USD hovering just below 0.6800 and AUD/USD near the middle of a 0.7270-15 band.

COMMODITIES

Brent (+0.2%) and WTI (Unch) are nursing initial losses as focus starts turning to the G20 summit over the weekend where markets may get initial hints of what to expect at the Dec 6th OPEC meeting in Vienna. The Saudi Crown Prince, Russian President and US President are to meet, possibly on the side-lines to decide the future of the global oil market. Talk around the market notes that Prince Mohammed Bin Salman may not able to defy US President Trump’s aim for lower oil prices after the White House stood behind the prince in regard to the killing of journalist Khashoggi. Nonetheless, traders will be watching the summit closely, while in the nearer-term, today will see the release of the weekly API where forecasts see headline crude stockpiles printing a drawdown of 0.6mln barrels.

Gold is trading relatively flat as the dollar holds steady following comments from Trump that overnight that he still intends to raise Chinese import tariffs to 25%; these comments come ahead of this week’s G20 summit. Additionally, US-China trade pessimism has caused copper prices to fall for the 3rd consecutive session due to demand concerns. Iron ore futures have dropped to their lowest level in over 4 months, dropping by 5% over concerns that steel prices are to remain pressured by slower demand.

Iraqi Oil Minster urges adopting a "balanced policy" in dealing with global oil market. (Newswires)

Kuwaiti Oil Minister says it is too early to talk about OPEC+ cuts. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

Gilts remain on the front foot on the back of latest Brexit deal rumblings and US-Sino tariff reports, with Trump upping the ante ahead the G20 Summit. UK 10 year futures are holding above 123.00 vs 123.23 at best, shrugging off significantly stronger than expected CBI trades, but losing some momentum alongside Bunds (just hovering below 161.00 vs 161.21 at the Eurex peak) and US Treasuries on a lack of follow-through buying in early trade. Elsewhere, Italian BTPs have traded up to 124.29 at one stage, before reverting to just below the 124.00 handle amidst yet more budget banter and short end supply. Ahead, more issuance to digest via the US 5 year auction, plus Fed's Clarida after 2nd tier data.

content: Gilts and Short Sterling contracts are on the front foot, with the 3 month strip outperforming core counterparts on the prospect of rejection at the next hurdle for the Brexit withdrawal agreement after a less than encouraging start to PM May’s campaign to convince MPs of the merits of the deal. On that note, the countdown to muster support for the proposal has begun in earnest with the date now set for the meaningful vote as December 11, and only 5 official days devoted to debate, although the attempts to garner support will be ongoing. Looking at Liffe price action in more detail, the 10 year UK benchmark bond has been above 123.00 from the off vs its previous 122.80 settlement price within 123.02-23 parameters and STIRs as much as 4 ticks ahead. Brexit aside, CBI distributive trades for November are due and forecast to improve.

Bunds: fading after firm rebound on renewed US-China trade and Brexit jitters
content: The core Eurozone bond has decoupled somewhat from its BTP vigil and inverse correlation amidst a shift in focus or rather a return to other major risks/uncertainties in the form of US vs China tariffs and Brexit. Bunds were marked up 16 ticks initially from Monday’s 160.74 Eurex close and then extended gains beyond 161.00 before retreating quite abruptly on headlines suggesting some mutual agreement between Presidents Trump and Xi on trade, which subsequently proved to be old news and referencing sentiment expressed in a call from November 1. Hence, the 10 year German debt future is back in the ascendency and just nudged up to 161.16 for a 42 tick gain on the day.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

27th November 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly positive as the region took impetus from the performance on Wall St, where all majors finished with firm gains on return from the Thanksgiving weekend and with retailers buoyed on the back of Black Friday and Cyber Monday sales. ASX 200 (+1.0%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) were lifted from the open with Australia led higher by tech and financials, while a pullback in USD/JPY limited the upside for the Japanese benchmark. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) were mixed with China somewhat dampened by Trump’s hardball tactics ahead of the meeting with Chinese President Xi at this week’s G20, in which he suggested an intention to proceed with raising tariffs on China imports from 10% to 25% and also warned to place tariffs on the remaining USD 267bln of Chinese imports if they fail to reach a favourable outcome for the US. Furthermore, a slowdown of Chinese Industrial Profit growth and concerns in the Hong Kong property sector also contributed the cautiousness in Chinese markets.

FTSE

Standard Chartered (STAN LN) – Co. is considering simplifying its structure in an attempt to cut costs across its networks from Zambia to Macau. (Newswires)

RELX PLC (REL LN) – The Co are planning a GBP 100mln takeover of the Times Higher Education weekly magazine. (Sky News)

BHP (BLT LN) – Co. have discovered potential new iron oxide, copper and gold mineralised systems around its Olympic Dam operations in South Australia. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

NMC HEALTH (NCM LN) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM FROM HOLD AT JEFFERIES

HIKMA PHARMACEUTICALS (HIK LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT JEFFERIES

DAX

Bayer (BAYN GY) – A drug owned by Co.’s US partner, Larotrectinib was shown to be effective against a wide range of cancers and has won FDA US approval, it will be sold under the name Vitrakvi in partnership with Bayer. (Newswires)

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY)/ Daimler (DAI GY) – Germany is pushing back against EU countries who are demanding more ambitious emission limits for trucks. Germany says CO2 cuts should not go beyond 15% by 2025 and 30% by 2030; according to EU documents. (Newswires)

Siemens (SIE GY)/ Alstom (ALO FP) – EU antitrust have hinted that the Co.s would have to give up valuable assets such as their advanced high-speed train tech and signalling unit to gain clearance for their merger; according to sources. (FT)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

FRESENIUS MEDICAL CARE (FME GY) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT BANKHAUS LAMPE

CAC

Renault (RNO FP) – Executives from the Co., Nissan and Mistubishi could meet as soon as Thursday, according to reports. (Newswires)

Accor (AC FP) – Co. is looking to double EBITDA through 2022 to reach a target of EUR 1.2bln, according to comments at their Capital Markets Day. Co also plans to buy the remaining stake of Poland’s Orbis for USD 500.95mln in order to strengthen its position in central Europe  (Newswires)

AXA (CS FP) – Co. plans to acquire the remaining 50% stake of its Chinese JV AXA Tianping for EUR 584mln. (FT)

Credit Agricole (ACA FP) – Co. said Credit Agricole Assurances was in talks to purchase Charterhouse’s Comexposium stake. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Imerys (NK FP) – Co. intends to simplify organisation to achieve greater customer focus as of Dec 1st 2018. (Newswires)

Vallourec (VK FP) – As of Sep 30th, Co. had EUR 769mln of cash and undrawn medium and long term confirmed facilities at EUR 2.2bln. Net debt at EUR 2.097bln. Co. targets a continued growth in oil and gas activity in 2019 while expecting further significant cost savings. Co. says each of these objectives should result in a higher EBITDA. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

REXEL (RXL FP) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM UNDERPERFROM AT CREDIT SUISSE

PAN EUROPE

Italian Telecom Names – The Italian Senate Finance committee has approved measures to spur the creation of a single broadband infrastructure company. (Newswires)

Koninklijke Vopak (VPK NA) – Co are beginning the commissioning of new chemical capacity in Deer Park, Houston this week; are confident that it will deliver short-term performance. RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 27th November 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets were mostly positive as the region took impetus from the performance on Wall St, where all majors finished with firm gains
  • US President Trump suggested an intention to proceed with raising tariffs on China imports from 10% to 25% and warned over tariffs on the remaining USD 267bln of Chinese imports if talks fail
  • US President Trump said it sounds like the Brexit deal is a good deal for the EU and that the UK may not be able to trade with the US
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US API Weekly Data, Fed's Powell, Clarida, Bostic, George & Evans, ECB's Mersch, Stournaras & Costa, Riksbank's Skingsley and Ohlsson

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly positive as the region took impetus from the performance on Wall St, where all majors finished with firm gains on return from the Thanksgiving weekend and with retailers buoyed on the back of Black Friday and Cyber Monday sales. ASX 200 (+1.0%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) were lifted from the open with Australia led higher by tech and financials, while a pullback in USD/JPY limited the upside for the Japanese benchmark. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) were mixed with China somewhat dampened by Trump’s hardball tactics ahead of the meeting with Chinese President Xi at this week’s G20, in which he suggested an intention to proceed with raising tariffs on China imports from 10% to 25% and also warned to place tariffs on the remaining USD 267bln of Chinese imports if they fail to reach a favourable outcome for the US. Furthermore, a slowdown of Chinese Industrial Profit growth and concerns in the Hong Kong property sector also contributed the cautiousness in Chinese markets. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful as prices took a breather from its extended but gradual uptrend and with today’s 40yr auction largely ignored despite increases in the b/c and accepted prices.

PBoC skipped open market operations for the 23rd consecutive occasion. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9463 (Prev. 6.9453)

Chinese Industrial Profits (Oct) Y/Y 3.6% (Prev. 4.1%). (Newswires)


UK/EU

UK PM May's spokesman said PM May still believes she can win the meaningful vote on Brexit and is focused on winning first time round, while the meaningful vote is expected on Tuesday 11th December and an official confirmed five days of debate between December 4th to December 11th. (Newswires)

US President Trump said it sounds like the Brexit deal is a good deal for the EU and that the UK may not be able to trade with the US. However, a UK No. 10 spokesperson later said declaration signed with EU is clear that UK can sign trade deals with the US and that UK has already been laying the groundwork for an ambitious trade deal with the US. (Newswires)

EU's Nowotny said a well communicated exit from QE may benefit financial health and poses little risk to financial stability, while he added very low rates for a long time may impair stability. (Newswires)

Italian PM Conte, following a meeting with Deputy PMs Salvini and Di Maio stated that the government will stick to its high-spending budget plans. (BBC) Later it was reported Italy’s 2019 deficit/GDP target is almost certain to be 2.2%, while PM Conte reportedly anticipates EUR 3.6bln of budget cuts according to reports in Messagerro. (Messagerro)
 

FX


FX markets were quiet in which the major pairs consolidated after the prior day’s price swings. Nonetheless, the DXY struggled to hold above the 97.00 level as EUR/USD and GBP/USD rebounded near Monday’s lows at the 1.1300 and 1.2800 handles respectively. Elsewhere, AUD and NZD attempted to nurse partial losses with the latter only briefly pressured after the latest New Zealand trade data showed a wider than expected deficit and slight miss on exports, while USD/JPY and JPY-crosses pulled-back as Trump’s renewed tariff threats spurred some flows into the safe-haven JPY.

New Zealand Trade Balance Oct -1295M vs. Exp. -850M (Prev. -1560.0M, Rev. -1596M). (Newswires)
New Zealand Exports Oct 4.86B vs. Exp. 4.88B (Prev. 4.33B, Rev. 4.25B)
New Zealand Imports Oct 6.15B vs. Exp. 5.84B (Prev. 5.89B, Rev. 5.84B)


COMMODITIES

Commodities saw tepid trade with WTI crude futures marginally weaker as prices remain pressured by Saudi Arabia’s record high production this month and although there were reports the kingdom was said to be keen on output cut agreement, this did little to spur oil prices which have slumped over 20% so far this month. Elsewhere, gold flatlined overnight amid an uneventful greenback, while copper was also subdued in-line with the lacklustre tone across the commodities complex and amid tariff concerns.

Saudi Arabia is said to be "keen" for an agreement to cut output despite the US wanting otherwise, while there were separate reports that Ecuador would support an OPEC production cut at meeting next week according to its Energy Minister. (FT/Newswires)

CME raised January 2019 crude oil futures NYMEX margins by 12.3% to USD 4,100 per contract and raised December RBOB gasoline futures margins by 7% to USD 4600 per contract. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

US Secretary of State Pompeo said Russia actions in the Kersch Strait is a dangerous escalation and in violation of international law. (Newswires)

US


The risk-on mood saw modest selling in the Treasury complex, where yields were higher by between 1-2bps at settlement; major curve spreads were generally little changed, with 2s5s and 2s10s slightly steeper, while 2s30s and 5s30s were narrower. The attention this week will be on Fed speak (with Powell set to speak twice, while VC Clarida is also on the slate) as well as the FOMC meeting minutes on Thursday, and the G20 meeting towards the end of the week. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 4+ ticks lower at 119-04+.

US President Trump said he still intends to go ahead with raising tariffs on China imports from 10% to 25% and that it was highly unlikely he would accept China’s request to refrain from the increase. Trump also suggested he would place tariffs on the rest of Chinese imports that are currently not subject to tariffs if the US doesn’t make a deal with China, while he added tariffs could be placed on Apple iPhones from China and that consumers could stand a 10% tariff on iPhones. (WSJ)

US Special Counsel Mueller's office said former Trump campaign manager Manafort lied to FBI and Special Counsel in violation of plea agreement. (Newswires)

Michelle Bowman was sworn into the Fed's Board of Governors. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia takes impetus from Wall St's strong performance, but with gains capped by Trump's hardball tactics
content:
Asia equity markets are mostly positive as they take impetus from the performance of their counterparts on Wall St, where all majors finished with firm gains on return from the Thanksgiving weekend with retailers buoyed on the back of Black Friday and Cyber Monday sales. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) were lifted from the open but with weakness in miners capping the tech and financials led advances in Australia, while a pullback in USD/JPY has limited the upside for the Japanese benchmark. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) are mixed with China somewhat dampened by Trump’s hardball tactics ahead of the meeting with Chinese President Xi at this week’s G20, as he suggested an intention to proceed with raising tariffs on China imports from 10% to 25% and also warned to place tariffs on the rest of Chinese imports if they fail to reach a favourable outcome for the US. Furthermore, a slowdown of Chinese Industrial Profit growth and concerns in the Hong Kong property sector has also added to the somewhat cautious tone in Chinese markets.

FX markets are quiet and have flatlined after the prior day’s price swings. As such, the DXY is flat and just about holds on to the 97.00 level as EUR/USD and GBP/USD languish near Monday’s lows at the 1.1300 and 1.2800 handles respectively. Elsewhere, AUD and NZD are uneventful with the latter mildly pressured after the latest New Zealand trade data showed a wider than expected deficit and slight miss on exports, while USD/JPY and JPY-crosses have pulled-back as Trump’s renewed tariff threats spurred some flows into the safe-haven JPY.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are uneventful as prices take a breather from its extended but gradual uptrend and with participants sidelined ahead of a 40yr auction later.
